Award.AwardTitle: NSF/DOE Partnership on Advanced Combustion Engines: Sooting Behavior of Conventional and Renewable Diesel-Fuel Compounds and Mixtures

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
CBET 1258654

PI: Lisa D. Pfefferle, Yale University; Co-PI: Charles S. McEnally, Yale University
Collaborator: Charles Mueller, Sandia National Laboratory
Collaborator: William Cannella, Chevron Corporation

This research will develop surrogate fuels that can replicate the sooting characteristics of conventional and alternative diesel fuels. Surrogate fuels are mixtures with only a few chemical components that mimic the properties of real fuels that contain thousands of components. They are necessary to perform computational simulations of diesel engines because any detailed chemical kinetic mechanism that included all of the significant components in real fuels would be prohibitively large and render computations unfeasible. During the project sooting tendencies will be measured in laboratory burners for individual components representative of diesel fuels. This data will be used to develop quantitative relationships between fuel structure and soot production that can be used to estimate sooting tendencies of unmeasured chemical compounds and aid in the development of less sooting fuels. Sooting tendencies will also be measured for mixtures to develop and test rules for predicting the sooting tendencies of mixtures from those of their individual components. Then sooting tendencies will be measured for real diesel fuels and surrogate mixtures formulated to have the same sooting tendency. Finally, the surrogates will be tested in the laboratory burners and in actual diesel engines.

Emissions of carbonaceous soot particles from diesel engines into the atmosphere directly harm human health; therefore new engine designs and concepts that improve fuel efficiency are only viable if they do not increase soot emissions. Computer aided design tools are critical for optimizing engines to be simultaneously efficient and nonpolluting and this is not possible using real fuels due to the large number of fuel components. This research will develop recipes for simple fuel mixtures that mimic soot formation in engines yet can be easily computed. In addition, the structure property relationships we develop will be broadly useful for scientists building surrogates for yet to be developed fuels.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes for the General Public

 

Sooting Behavior of Conventional and Renewable Diesel Fuel Compounds and Mixtures

NSF/DOE Partnership for Advanced Engine Combustion

Lisa Pfefferle, Charles McEnally

Yale University

 

The goal of this project was to reduce emissions of carbonaceous soot particles from internal combustion engines. Soot and other fine particulates suspended in ambient air are estimated to cause over 3 million deaths worldwide each year. Moreover, soot contributes directly to global warming by absorbing sunlight and heating the atmosphere; recent studies indicate that it is the second most important source of climate change and has a radiative forcing only one-third less than CO2. Finally, soot also effectively impedes automotive fuel economy since engine strategies that improve efficiency, such as gasoline direct injection (GDI) and compression ignition (CI; i.e., diesel engines), tend to increase its emissions.

 

In principle, automotive engineers can use computer simulations to design engines that optimize the tradeoffs between high efficiency and low emissions. However, gasoline and diesel fuel are chemically complex mixtures containing thousands of hydrocarbons, so in simulations these real fuels have to be replaced by simplified “surrogate” fuels that include just a few components. The final engine design will only be optimized to the extent that the surrogate fuel behaves the same as the target fuel. In this project we sought to develop the scientific knowledge necessary to rationally formulate surrogate fuels that could mimic the sooting behavior of real diesel fuels.

 

We quantified the sooting propensity of each fuel of interest by the amount of soot formed in a simple laboratory methane/air flame when a trace amount of the fuel was added to the methane. The result for each fuel is referred to as its Yield Sooting Index (YSI). The basic idea is that the greater the tendency of the fuel to form soot, the more soot it will produce in the flame, the more soot we will measure, and the greater will be its YSI. The purpose of the methane/air flame is to approximate the reactive environment of an engine; since only a trace amount of the test fuel is added, the flame provides the same environment for all test fuels.

 

During the course of this study, we measured YSI’s of over 30 real fuels, surrogate fuel mixtures, and many pure surrogate components. Many of the fuel samples were provided by our collaborators at Sandia National Laboratories and Chevron Energy Technologies. We were able to rank the surrogates by their ability to mimic the sooting behavior of the real diesel fuels, and identify surrogates that matched the YSI of a certification diesel fuel to within experimental uncertainty. We demonstrated that the database of YSI’s measured for pure hydrocarbons, in combination with a simple linear additivity rule, can predict the YSI of any mixture. Moreover, we derived a correlation between YSI and the distribution of chemically-distinct carbon atoms in the fuel and showed it can also predict YSI. Thus this project successfully produced methods for characterizing the sooting propensity of a target diesel fuel, for formulating a surrogate mixture that reproduces that propensity, and for verifying that the surrogate is accurate.

 

In an effort to maximize the impact of this study, we are making all of the data widely available by posting it to our flame data website (http://guilford.eng.yale.edu/yalecoflowflames/) and to our Dataverse (https://dataverse.harvard.edu/dataverse/pfefferle). To promote STEM education we involved three high school students and five undergraduates – half of them women – in this project, and most of the funding was used to financially support graduate students.
